newsitem.title: USA: Criteria set for viewing Oklahoma bomb telecast.
newsitem.headline: Criteria set for viewing Oklahoma bomb telecast.

text.p: Oklahoma City bombing victims who want to view a closed-circuit telecast of the trials will be asked if they suffered physical or emotional injury or financial loss, according to questionnaires made public on Thursday.

More than 2,000 victims may be vying for 330 seats in a Federal Aviation Administration facility in Oklahoma City where the telecast will be shown. Congress mandated a closed-circuit telecast of the trials only for victims who are unable, because of expense and inconvenience, to attend the trials in Denver.
Timothy McVeigh and Terry Nichols are charged in the April 1995 bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah federal building that claimed the lives of 168 people and injured several hundred.
U.S. District Court Judge Richard Matsch moved the trials to Denver, saying the defendants could not get fair hearings in Oklahoma.

The forms ask victims whether they suffered physical or emotional injury such as the death or injury of a relative. Victims also are asked if they sustained financial loss from the closure of a business or bankruptcy.

The Justice Department has recommended to Matsch that eligible victims be allowed to attend the telecast on a rotating basis so more of them can watch during the trials which are expected to last several months.
McVeigh's trial begins on March 31. A date for Nichols' trial has not been set.
